content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy and beginner-friendly clash; the hardest part seems to be understanding the statement.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and easily solvable

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and simple problem.
I didn't try it in reverse though, will leave that to someone else :)
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

For anyone wanting to test this in Reverse mode, here are the test cases (without validators), commented so you can paste them into the IDE and try solving without looking at the statement:
#Input
#1
#13
#Output
#hexadecimal
#3
#Input
#2
#256
#Output
#hexadecimal
#0
#Input
#1
#36
#Output
#base 36
#0
#Input
#2
#1000
#Output
#base 36
#296
#Input
#7
#100000000
#Output
#hexadecimal
#168435456
#Input
#7
#800000000
#Output
#base 36
#77564164096

Goal
* Please format "the number of 'spare' ID's" in <<bold>> instead of as a {{constant}}.

* The note may be deleted. It is covered by the 3rd constraint.

Output
* Please format "number of 'spare' ID's" in <<bold>> instead of as a {{constant}}.

Constraints
* The 3rd constraint is sufficient to imply the condition stated in 4th constraint. The 4th constraint may be deleted.

Cases
* As Validator 6 is the only case where the output is greater than 2**32, it's better to swap Test 6 and Validator 6 to avoid any nasty surprises. Suggest to swap Test 5 and Validator 5 as well, so that the output of "base 36" and "hexadecimal" are balanced for tests and validators.

Thanks.

Here's the code I use to produce this from copy+pasted tests and validators, if you want to use it for other clashes too:
https://ato.pxeger.com/run?1=dZLfbpswFMa1XfopjuAioG6U_0kmVVGl9iLSpEpd1JuxrS44iiewETbpsoSX2O1uctG-VJ9mhpCGNMw3GOv7vt85Pv77VJQPq-32uZTzj6OXd38KsoQLkEVJoLv03RGdw4qX8IiZBLmgAua8gFuyJIUgkPGEgEEtYgHjsMQpTbDkhfgAnKUrkERIiLEgwkQxzzKiMo5JvRACvMxLCSllREBekJgkJIFHKheg6RoI3qhjzCDHQiq7BMokb6zTq2uEFeU-Se4toTTGuXU2MSafZtdfZvp6sLm7_Dy9upzd3A5KlhIhQPVfmREzpkxB643S15-bUnYOjMlFxL5-j9i3szbskGRuot_meWYipReArQzn602xgcL6ySkztIhppiXylMp2Xws0VYw-qFtvr6bS1z-cSqug2o2mndD25X04qy_SgZqKmjKRgxwP7SpEC_ILJySmGU6Rh-72U1CG1woPLqfPFaCG4HYJLnKDsE9sdxDuCcJDvj3-j6-BeMdteK_aB_VQQP12872TfBc57rjH02T7xw04tm2_VdbmQ77fV3_YYwvVXTSIoIsYNohm9XXshCPfC_ygSwxOiP4-5IQ5HIdOiw2PsaO32L1nOAxC3wmbGezezz8

Ok, with reverse I had no idea. I do know hexidecimal, but I never worked with base 36 before --> it made me wonder whether I would also need to take into account the possibility of encountering base 20, or base 30, or some random other base. Also, I am not sure whether I ever would have connected one of the values to 'spare'.

It might help me if there is one or two more very easy ones at the start (now, the first one is a simple hex, the second one is already a bit of a special case with 0, and the third is already base 36).
I have now added an extra test case pair after the first pair, with n = 1 and solvable with hexadecimal. Hopefully that makes it a bit easier to reverse-engineer.
